item.title: Auto-Claude: Autonomous Multi-Session AI Coding That 10x Your Development Output
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Auto-Claude is a revolutionary desktop application created by AndyMik90 that transforms how developers interact with AI coding assistants. Unlike traditional single-session AI coding tools, Auto-Claude enables you to run up to 12 parallel Claude Code terminals simultaneously, each working on different tasks while maintaining complete isolation through git worktrees.

Whether you’re a “vibe coder” just getting started or an experienced developer managing complex projects, Auto-Claude meets you where you are with autonomous agents that plan, code, and validate for you.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • 10x Development Output: Run multiple builds simultaneously while maintaining code quality
  • 12 Parallel Agent Terminals: Clean layout with smart naming and one-click context injection
  • Git Worktree Isolation: All work happens safely without disturbing your main branch
  • Self-Validating QA: Built-in agents check their own work before you review
  • Cross-Session Memory: Agents remember insights across sessions using FalkorDB graph database
  • AI Merge Resolution: Intelligent conflict resolution when merging back to main
  • Cross-Platform: Desktop app runs on Mac, Windows, and Linux

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Auto-Claude, ensure you have the following components:

RequirementVersionPurpose
Node.js18+Desktop UI runtime
Python3.10+Backend agent execution
Docker DesktopLatestMemory Layer (FalkorDB)
Claude Code CLILatestAI coding engine
Claude SubscriptionPro or MaxRequired for Claude Code access
Git Repository-Worktree isolation

Git Initialization

Section titled “Git Initialization”

Auto-Claude requires a git repository to create isolated worktrees for safe parallel development:

Git worktrees allow you to work on multiple features simultaneously without conflicts, keeping your main branch clean until you’re ready to merge.

Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Installation and Configuration”

Step 1: Clone Auto-Claude

Section titled “Step 1: Clone Auto-Claude”

Step 2: Set Up Python Backend

Section titled “Step 2: Set Up Python Backend”

Step 3: Start the Memory Layer

Section titled “Step 3: Start the Memory Layer”

The Memory Layer provides cross-session context retention using FalkorDB:

Step 4: Install and Launch Desktop UI

Section titled “Step 4: Install and Launch Desktop UI”

Windows Users

Section titled “Windows Users”

If installation fails with node-gyp errors:

  1. Download Visual Studio Build Tools 2022
  2. Select “Desktop development with C++” workload
  3. Add “MSVC v143 - VS 2022 C++ x64/x86 Spectre-mitigated libs”
  4. Restart terminal and run npm install again

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Kanban Board Interface

Section titled “1. Kanban Board Interface”

Plan tasks and let AI handle planning, coding, and validation in a visual interface. Track progress from “Planning” to “Done” while agents work autonomously.

2. Agent Terminals

Section titled “2. Agent Terminals”

Spawn up to 12 AI-powered terminals for hands-on coding:

  • Inject task context with a click
  • Reference files from your project
  • Work rapidly across multiple sessions
  • Connect multiple Claude Code subscriptions for teams

3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline

Section titled “3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline”

Phase 1: Spec Creation (3-8 phases)

  • Discovery — Analyzes project structure and tech stack
  • Requirements — Gathers requirements through interactive conversation
  • Research — Validates external integrations against real documentation
  • Context Discovery — Finds relevant files in your codebase
  • Spec Writer — Creates comprehensive specification document
  • Spec Critic — Self-critiques using extended thinking
  • Planner — Breaks work into subtasks with dependencies
  • Validation — Ensures all outputs are valid

Phase 2: Implementation

  • Planner Agent creates subtask-based implementation plan
  • Coder Agent implements subtasks one-by-one with verification
  • QA Reviewer validates all acceptance criteria
  • QA Fixer fixes issues in a self-healing loop (up to 50 iterations)

Phase 3: Merge

  • Conflict Detection identifies modified files
  • 3-Tier Resolution: Git auto-merge → Conflict-only AI → Full-file AI
  • Parallel Merge for multiple files simultaneously
  • Staged for Review before finalizing

4. Memory Layer Architecture

Section titled “4. Memory Layer Architecture”

The Memory Layer combines graph nodes with semantic search:

SetupLLMEmbeddingsNotes
OpenAIOpenAIOpenAISimplest - single API key
Anthropic + VoyageAnthropicVoyage AIHigh quality
Google AIGeminiGoogleFast inference
OllamaOllamaOllamaFully offline
AzureAzure OpenAIAzure OpenAIEnterprise

5. Security Model

Section titled “5. Security Model”

Three-layer defense keeps your code safe:

  • OS Sandbox: Bash commands run in isolation
  • Filesystem Restrictions: Operations limited to project directory
  • Command Allowlist: Only approved commands based on your project’s stack

Recommended Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios”

Scenario 1: Feature Development Sprint

Section titled “Scenario 1: Feature Development Sprint”

Run 4-6 parallel agents working on different features:

Scenario 2: Bug Fixing Marathon

Section titled “Scenario 2: Bug Fixing Marathon”

Assign different bug reports to separate agents:

Scenario 3: Codebase Modernization

Section titled “Scenario 3: Codebase Modernization”

Let agents handle different modernization tasks:

  • Refactoring legacy code
  • Updating dependencies
  • Adding TypeScript types
  • Improving test coverage

Scenario 4: Team Collaboration

Section titled “Scenario 4: Team Collaboration”

Power users can connect multiple Claude Code subscriptions:

  • Each team member runs their own set of agents
  • Shared Memory Layer preserves project context
  • AI handles merge conflicts across branches

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

  1. Start with Clear Specifications: Provide detailed task descriptions for better agent performance

  2. Use Git Worktrees: Let Auto-Claude manage isolation - never work directly on main during builds

  3. Review QA Reports: Check the self-validation results before accepting changes

  4. Leverage Memory Layer: Enable FalkorDB for better context across sessions

  5. Batch Similar Tasks: Group related work to maximize parallel efficiency

  6. Monitor Resource Usage: 12 parallel agents can be resource-intensive - adjust based on your hardware

Comparison with Similar Tools

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Tools”
FeatureAuto-ClaudeClaude CodeCursorAider
Parallel SessionsUp to 12111
Git Worktree Isolation✅❌❌❌
Self-Validating QA✅❌❌❌
Cross-Session Memory✅ (FalkorDB)❌✅❌
AI Merge Resolution✅❌❌❌
Desktop UI✅CLI✅CLI
Kanban Board✅❌❌❌

Precautions and FAQ

Section titled “Precautions and FAQ”

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  1. Claude Subscription Required: You need Claude Pro or Max for Claude Code access
  2. Resource Intensive: Running 12 parallel agents requires significant CPU/RAM
  3. Docker Dependency: Memory Layer requires Docker Desktop running
  4. AGPL-3.0 License: Commercial use requires open-sourcing your modifications

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Auto-Claude different from regular Claude Code? A: Auto-Claude wraps Claude Code with parallel execution, git worktree isolation, self-validating QA, and cross-session memory. It’s a productivity multiplier, not a replacement.

Q: Can I use this with my existing project? A: Yes! Just ensure your project is a git repository. Auto-Claude creates isolated worktrees without modifying your main branch.

Q: How many agents should I run? A: Start with 2-4 and scale up based on your hardware. Each agent consumes Claude Code API credits separately.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The Memory Layer supports Ollama for fully offline operation, but Claude Code requires internet connectivity.

Q: What happens if an agent gets stuck? A: The QA Fixer runs up to 50 iterations in a self-healing loop. If it still fails, you can review and intervene manually.

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • GitHub Repository
  • Discord Community
  • Docker Setup Guide
  • CLI Usage Guide
  • Contributing Guidelines
  • Anthropic Autonomous Coding Agent (Inspiration)

Auto-Claude represents the next evolution in AI-assisted development - transforming single-session coding into a parallel, autonomous workflow that multiplies developer productivity while maintaining code quality through self-validation.

item.title: Beads: A Memory Upgrade for Your AI Coding Agent
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Beads (bd) is a distributed, git-backed graph issue tracker designed specifically for AI coding agents. Created by Steve Yegge (former Google/Amazon engineer and renowned software blogger), Beads solves one of the most frustrating problems in AI-assisted development: the context window limitation.

When you start a new session with your AI coding assistant, it loses all understanding of your project goals and progress. Beads provides a persistent, structured memory that replaces messy markdown plans with a dependency-aware graph, allowing agents to handle long-horizon tasks without losing context.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • Git as Database: Issues stored as JSONL in .beads/, versioned and merged like code
  • Agent-Optimized: JSON output, dependency tracking, and auto-ready task detection
  • Zero Conflict: Hash-based IDs prevent merge collisions in multi-agent workflows
  • Invisible Infrastructure: SQLite local cache with background daemon for auto-sync
  • Memory Compaction: Semantic summarization of old tasks to save context window

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Beads, ensure you have:

  • Operating System: Linux (glibc 2.32+), macOS, or Windows 11
  • Git: Version control system (for syncing and collaboration)
  • Go 1.24+ (optional, for building from source)

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Quick Install (Recommended)

Section titled “Quick Install (Recommended)”

Package Managers

Section titled “Package Managers”

MCP Server Installation

Section titled “MCP Server Installation”

For Claude Desktop or other MCP-only environments:

Verify Installation

Section titled “Verify Installation”

Configuration

Section titled “Configuration”

Initialize a Project

Section titled “Initialize a Project”

This creates a .beads/ directory with the SQLite database and JSONL export file.

Agent Setup

Section titled “Agent Setup”

Configure beads for your preferred AI coding assistant:

This adds approximately 1-2k tokens of context to your agent’s instructions.

Stealth Mode

Section titled “Stealth Mode”

Use Beads locally without committing to the main repo:

Perfect for personal use on shared projects where you don’t want to affect team workflows.

Essential Commands

Section titled “Essential Commands”
CommandDescription
bd readyList tasks with no open blockers
bd create "Title" -p 0Create a P0 (highest priority) task
bd dep add <child> <parent>Link tasks with dependencies
bd show <id>View task details and audit trail
bd close <id>Mark a task as completed
bd syncForce immediate synchronization
bd compactSummarize old closed tasks
bd quickstartInteractive guide for AI agents
bd dep treeVisualize hierarchical relationships

Recommended Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios”

1. Long-Horizon Feature Development

Section titled “1. Long-Horizon Feature Development”

When building complex features that span multiple sessions:

2. Multi-Agent Collaboration

Section titled “2. Multi-Agent Collaboration”

Hash-based IDs prevent conflicts when multiple agents work simultaneously:

3. Daily Workflow

Section titled “3. Daily Workflow”

Morning Standup:

During Work:

End of Session (Critical):

4. Project Planning with AI

Section titled “4. Project Planning with AI”

Tell your agent to use beads for task management:

Your AI agent can now:

  • Query for ready tasks instead of loading entire spec files
  • Create and link tasks as it discovers work
  • Mark tasks complete with audit trail
  • Maintain context across session boundaries

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics

Section titled “1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics”

2. Leverage Dependency Types

Section titled “2. Leverage Dependency Types”

Beads supports four dependency types:

  • blocks: Task A must complete before Task B
  • related: Tasks are conceptually linked
  • parent-child: Hierarchical organization
  • discovered-from: Task found while working on another

3. Batch Operations

Section titled “3. Batch Operations”

When making multiple changes, batch within 30 seconds:

4. Use Compaction for Large Projects

Section titled “4. Use Compaction for Large Projects”

This implements “agentic memory decay” - LLMs summarize old closed issues, replacing detailed content with concise summaries.

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”

Alpha Software Warning

Section titled “Alpha Software Warning”

Beads is currently in alpha (v0.9.x). While stable for development:

  • Avoid using in critical production systems until 1.0 release
  • Back up important data regularly
  • Report issues on GitHub

Git Dependency

Section titled “Git Dependency”

Beads relies entirely on Git for synchronization:

  • Ensure git push completes successfully before ending sessions
  • The “plane has NOT landed until git push completes”

Context Window Consideration

Section titled “Context Window Consideration”

While Beads reduces context consumption, complex queries can still use significant tokens. Use targeted queries (bd ready) rather than full dumps.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?

Section titled “Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?”

A: Beads offers:

  • Typed dependencies with semantic meaning
  • Offline-first design with local SQLite
  • Git-native sync without external services
  • Hash-based IDs preventing multi-agent collisions
  • Agent-optimized output (JSON format)

Q: Can I use Beads offline?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Beads offline?”

A: Yes! All queries run against local SQLite. Sync happens via git push/pull when network is available.

Q: What about existing issue trackers?

Section titled “Q: What about existing issue trackers?”

A: Beads complements rather than replaces tools like Jira or GitHub Issues. Use Beads for AI agent memory and local development; sync important issues to your main tracker.

Q: How do I migrate from markdown-based planning?

Section titled “Q: How do I migrate from markdown-based planning?”

A: Create beads issues from your existing todos:

Q: Does Beads work with multiple AI assistants?

Section titled “Q: Does Beads work with multiple AI assistants?”

A: Yes! Hash-based IDs prevent collisions. Configure each assistant:

Comparison with Similar Tools

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Tools”
FeatureBeadsGitHub IssuesJiraLinear
Git-native✅❌❌❌
Offline-first✅❌❌❌
Agent-optimized✅❌❌❌
Dependency graph✅Limited✅✅
Free/Open Source✅✅❌❌
Memory compaction✅❌❌❌
Hash-based IDs✅❌❌❌

Community Tools

Section titled “Community Tools”

The Beads ecosystem includes several community-built tools:

  • beads_viewer - Keyboard-driven terminal UI with kanban board
  • beads.el - Emacs UI for beads management
  • beads-ui - Local web interface with live updates
  • bdui - Real-time terminal UI with vim-style navigation
  • perles - Terminal UI with BQL (Beads Query Language)
  • vscode-beads - VS Code extension

References

Section titled “References”
  • GitHub Repository: steveyegge/beads
  • npm Package: @beads/bd
  • PyPI Package: beads-mcp
  • Go Package: github.com/steveyegge/beads
  • BetterStack Guide: Beads Issue Tracker for AI Agents
  • Steve Yegge’s LinkedIn Announcement

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Beads represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI coding assistants. Instead of treating them as stateless tools that forget everything between sessions, Beads gives them persistent, structured memory that grows with your project.

By leveraging Git’s familiar workflow, providing agent-optimized queries, and implementing intelligent memory compaction, Beads enables truly long-horizon task management. Whether you’re working solo or coordinating multiple AI agents, Beads ensures your coding assistants never lose track of the bigger picture.

Get started today:

Your AI coding agent’s memory just got a major upgrade.

item.title: Accenture × Anthropic: 30,000 Claude Practitioners to Transform Enterprise AI
item.content:encoded:
From AI Pilots to Production: The Largest Claude Deployment in History

💡 The Big News

Section titled “💡 The Big News”

On December 9, 2025, two tech giants announced a game-changing partnership. Accenture and Anthropic are joining forces in a multi-year deal that will fundamentally reshape how enterprises adopt AI.

This isn’t just another AI partnership announcement. It’s the largest Claude deployment ever, with approximately 30,000 Accenture professionals being trained on Claude—creating one of the world’s largest ecosystems of Claude practitioners.

🎯 Why This Partnership Matters

Section titled “🎯 Why This Partnership Matters”

The Enterprise AI Challenge

Section titled “The Enterprise AI Challenge”

Many organizations are stuck in “AI pilot purgatory”—running endless experiments without achieving production-scale deployment. This partnership directly addresses that gap.

Key Numbers

Section titled “Key Numbers”
MetricValue
Professionals to be trained~30,000
Anthropic’s enterprise market shareGrew from 24% to 40%
Claude Code market shareOver 50% of AI coding market
Partnership durationMulti-year (3 years per WSJ)

🔧 Three Pillars of the Partnership

Section titled “🔧 Three Pillars of the Partnership”

1. Accenture Anthropic Business Group

Section titled “1. Accenture Anthropic Business Group”

A dedicated strategic unit making Anthropic one of Accenture’s select partners. This group will:

  • Train 30,000+ professionals on Claude
  • Deploy forward-deployed engineers (called “reinvention deployed engineers” at Accenture)
  • Embed Claude directly within client environments

Why it matters: These engineers don’t just implement—they help organizations scale AI adoption with reduced risk and faster deployment timelines.

2. Claude Center of Excellence

Section titled “2. Claude Center of Excellence”

Anthropic and Accenture will co-invest in a dedicated Claude Center of Excellence inside Accenture. This environment focuses on:

  • Joint design of new AI offerings
  • Tailored solutions for specific enterprise needs
  • Industry-specific requirements and regulatory compliance
  • Custom regulatory context solutions

Why it matters: This isn’t off-the-shelf AI. It’s enterprise AI built for complex, regulated industries.

3. CIO Offering for Engineering Organizations

Section titled “3. CIO Offering for Engineering Organizations”

The first product from this partnership targets technology leaders:

ComponentDescription
Claude Code IntegrationAI coding at the center of the enterprise SDLC
Productivity FrameworkQuantify real productivity gains and ROI
Workflow RedesignAI-first development team structures
Change ManagementTraining and organizational transformation

Why it matters: For the first time, CIOs get a structured way to measure and drive large-scale AI adoption across engineering organizations.

🏭 Industry Focus: Regulated Sectors First

Section titled “🏭 Industry Focus: Regulated Sectors First”

The partnership is strategically targeting highly regulated industries where AI adoption is most challenging—and most valuable:

Financial Services

Section titled “Financial Services”
  • Compliance workflow automation
  • Precision decision-making systems
  • Regulatory reporting automation

Life Sciences & Healthcare

Section titled “Life Sciences & Healthcare”
  • Proprietary dataset analysis
  • Clinical trial processing acceleration
  • Research documentation automation

Public Sector

Section titled “Public Sector”
  • AI agents for government service navigation
  • Data privacy-compliant solutions
  • Citizen service enhancement

Why start here? These sectors face the dual challenge of modernizing legacy systems while maintaining strict security and governance requirements. Success here proves the model works everywhere.

📣 Leadership Perspectives

Section titled “📣 Leadership Perspectives”

Dario Amodei, CEO and Co-founder of Anthropic:

“Our new partnership means tens of thousands of Accenture developers will be using Claude Code, making this our largest deployment ever.”

Julie Sweet, Chair and CEO of Accenture:

“This expansion will help our clients accelerate the shift from experimenting with AI to using it as a catalyst for reinvention across the enterprise.”

🚀 What This Means for Enterprises

Section titled “🚀 What This Means for Enterprises”

For Technology Leaders

Section titled “For Technology Leaders”
  • Proven deployment model: 30,000 trained professionals means battle-tested implementation patterns
  • Reduced risk: Forward-deployed engineers handle the complexity
  • Measurable ROI: First CIO offering with built-in productivity metrics

For Development Teams

Section titled “For Development Teams”
  • Claude Code access: Premier AI coding tools at enterprise scale
  • Workflow integration: AI-first development practices built in
  • Training pipeline: Access to one of the world’s largest Claude practitioner ecosystems

For Regulated Industries

Section titled “For Regulated Industries”
  • Compliance-first approach: Solutions designed for regulatory requirements
  • Industry expertise: Tailored offerings for financial services, healthcare, and public sector
  • Security focus: Enterprise-grade data privacy and governance

🔮 The Bigger Picture

Section titled “🔮 The Bigger Picture”

This partnership signals a major shift in the AI industry:

  1. From experiments to production: The enterprise AI market is maturing
  2. Consulting + AI vendor alignment: Deep integration beats surface-level partnerships
  3. Regulated industries first: Proving AI works in the hardest environments
  4. Developer tools as enterprise entry point: Claude Code’s 50%+ market share makes it the wedge

Anthropic’s enterprise market share growing from 24% to 40% isn’t just a number—it’s evidence that enterprises are betting on Claude for their most critical AI initiatives.

🧠 Summary

Section titled “🧠 Summary”

The Accenture-Anthropic partnership represents:

  • The largest Claude deployment ever (30,000+ professionals)
  • A new model for enterprise AI adoption (embedded engineers + Center of Excellence)
  • A focus on the hardest problems (regulated industries)
  • Measurable business outcomes (CIO offering with ROI frameworks)

For enterprises stuck in AI pilot purgatory, this partnership offers a clear path from experimentation to production-scale transformation.

Sources:

  • Anthropic News
  • Accenture Newsroom
  • TechCrunch

📣 What’s your take on enterprise AI adoption? Share your thoughts in the comments!

item.title: Claude Code System Prompts Revealed: Inside the AI That Powers Your Coding
item.content:encoded:
Discover the Hidden Architecture Behind Anthropic’s AI Coding Assistant

The Discovery

Section titled “The Discovery”

Ever wondered what makes Claude Code tick? Thanks to the open-source community, specifically the Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository, we now have unprecedented visibility into the intricate system prompts that power one of the most popular AI coding assistants on the market.

This repository, maintained by the team behind Piebald, provides a comprehensive breakdown of all Claude Code’s various system prompts, updated with each new version. As of Claude Code v2.0.75 (December 20th, 2025), it covers 56 versions of changelog since v2.0.14.

Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts

Section titled “Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts”

Claude Code doesn’t just have one single string for its system prompt. Instead, there are multiple components working together:

Component TypeDescription
Conditional PromptsLarge portions added depending on environment and configs
Tool DescriptionsBuiltin tools like Write, Bash, and TodoWrite
Agent PromptsSeparate system prompts for Explore, Plan, and Task agents
Utility FunctionsAI-powered features like conversation compaction, CLAUDE.md generation

The result is 40+ strings that are constantly changing and moving within a very large minified JS file.

Key Prompt Categories

Section titled “Key Prompt Categories”

1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)

Section titled “1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)”

The core system prompt defines Claude Code’s fundamental behavior:

Communication Style:

  • Responses should be “short and concise” for command-line display
  • Uses GitHub-flavored markdown formatted for monospace fonts
  • Avoids emojis unless explicitly requested
  • Tools are for task completion only, not user communication

Technical Approach:

  • Prioritizes technical accuracy and truthfulness
  • Provides direct, objective technical info
  • Reads files before proposing modifications
  • Avoids over-engineering and unnecessary abstractions

2. Agent Prompts

Section titled “2. Agent Prompts”

Sub-agents

Section titled “Sub-agents”
AgentTokensPurpose
Explore516System prompt for the Explore subagent
Plan Mode (Enhanced)633Enhanced prompt for the Plan subagent
Task Tool294System prompt for Task tool spawned subagents

Creation Assistants

Section titled “Creation Assistants”
AgentTokensPurpose
Agent Creation Architect1,111Creating custom AI agents with detailed specifications
CLAUDE.md Creation384Analyzing codebases and creating CLAUDE.md files
Status Line Setup1,310Configuring status line display

3. Slash Commands

Section titled “3. Slash Commands”
CommandTokensPurpose
/pr-comments402Fetching and displaying GitHub PR comments
/review-pr243Reviewing GitHub pull requests
/security-review2,610Comprehensive security review for code changes

4. Utility Prompts

Section titled “4. Utility Prompts”
UtilityTokensPurpose
Bash Command Prefix Detection835Detecting command prefixes and injection
Conversation Summarization1,121+Creating detailed conversation summaries
Claude Guide Agent763Helping users understand Claude Code
Session Title Generation333Generating titles and git branch names
WebFetch Summarizer185Summarizing verbose web fetch output

Builtin Tool Descriptions

Section titled “Builtin Tool Descriptions”

Claude Code’s builtin tools have their own detailed descriptions:

ToolTokensDescription
Bash1,074Run shell commands with safety guidelines
TodoWrite2,167Task list management with best practices
Task1,214Launching specialized sub-agents
EnterPlanMode970Entering plan mode for implementation design
ReadFile439Reading files with multimodal support
Edit278Exact string replacements in files
Write159Creating/overwriting files
Grep300Content search using ripgrep

Recent Changelog Highlights

Section titled “Recent Changelog Highlights”

The system prompts are constantly evolving. Here are key recent changes:

v2.0.75 (December 20, 2025)

Section titled “v2.0.75 (December 20, 2025)”
  • Streamlined task tool instructions
  • Removed directive against using colons before tool calls

v2.0.74

Section titled “v2.0.74”
  • New “Session Search Assistant” agent for finding relevant sessions
  • Removed delegate mode restrictions

v2.0.73

Section titled “v2.0.73”
  • Added “Prompt Suggestion Generator v2” with improved intent prediction
  • Merged slash command functionality into the Skill tool
  • Expanded LSP capabilities with call hierarchy operations

v2.0.71

Section titled “v2.0.71”
  • Introduced browser automation support via new Computer tool
  • Chrome-based task execution enabled

v2.0.62

Section titled “v2.0.62”
  • Major planning philosophy shift: EnterPlanMode rewritten to encourage proactive planning for non-trivial tasks

Practical Applications

Section titled “Practical Applications”

For Developers

Section titled “For Developers”

Understanding these prompts helps you:

  1. Work more effectively with Claude Code - Knowing its priorities and constraints
  2. Craft better prompts - Align your requests with Claude Code’s design
  3. Debug unexpected behavior - Understand why certain responses occur

For AI Enthusiasts

Section titled “For AI Enthusiasts”

This transparency offers:

  1. Learning opportunities - Study how production AI systems are prompted
  2. Best practices - See how Anthropic structures complex multi-agent systems
  3. Research material - Compare prompting strategies across tools

The tweakcc Tool

Section titled “The tweakcc Tool”

Want to customize Claude Code’s system prompts? The Piebald team also created tweakcc, which lets you:

  • Customize individual pieces of the system prompt as markdown files
  • Patch your npm-based or native Claude Code installation
  • Manage conflicts when both you and Anthropic modify the same prompt file

About Piebald

Section titled “About Piebald”

Piebald is described as “the ultimate agentic AI developer experience.” It supports:

  • Multi-provider APIs: OpenAI-compatible, Anthropic-compatible, or Google-compatible
  • Credential imports: From Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and Codex CLI
  • Full customization: Prompts, model settings, and reusable profiles

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

The Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository provides unprecedented insight into how Claude Code works internally:

  • 40+ prompt strings working together
  • Multiple agent types for different tasks
  • Detailed tool descriptions guiding behavior
  • Constant evolution across 56+ versions

This transparency benefits the entire AI development community by showing how production AI coding assistants are architected.

Sources:

  • Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts
  • tweakcc
  • Piebald

Have you explored Claude Code’s system prompts? What insights have you discovered? Share in the comments!

item.title: A2UI: Google's Agent-Driven Interface Protocol That Changes Everything
item.content:encoded:
From Text-Only Responses to Rich, Native UIs: How Google’s A2UI Protocol Enables AI Agents to Generate Interactive Interfaces

1. Introduction: Features and Highlights

Section titled “1. Introduction: Features and Highlights”

What is A2UI?

Section titled “What is A2UI?”

On December 15, 2025, Google publicly launched A2UI (Agent to UI), an open-source protocol that enables AI agents to generate rich, interactive user interfaces that render natively across platforms—without executing arbitrary code.

Think about it: instead of an AI agent responding with just text, it can now send back a complete, interactive form, a data visualization card, or a booking confirmation interface. The magic? Your app renders these UIs using native components, maintaining your design system while benefiting from AI-generated interfaces.

Core Problem Solved

Section titled “Core Problem Solved”

Traditional agent interactions face a fundamental tension:

ApproachProblem
Text-only responsesLimited expressiveness, tedious back-and-forth
HTML/JavaScript in iframesSecurity risks, sandboxing complexity, no native styling
A2UI approachDeclarative JSON data + native rendering = best of both worlds

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Security-FirstDeclarative data format (not executable code). Agents can only render pre-approved components from your catalog
LLM-FriendlyFlat component lists with ID references, easy for LLMs to generate incrementally
Framework-AgnosticWorks with React, Flutter, Angular, SwiftUI, Lit, and more
Transport-AgnosticCompatible with A2A, AG-UI, REST (experimental)
Progressive RenderingUsers see UI building in real-time as LLMs generate

Who’s Behind It?

Section titled “Who’s Behind It?”
  • Core Team: Google A2UI Team
  • Key Partners: CopilotKit/AG-UI (day-zero compatibility), Opal (core contributor), Gemini Enterprise
  • License: Apache 2.0
  • Current Version: v0.8 (Public Preview)

2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before getting started, ensure you have:

  • Node.js (for web clients and renderers)
  • Python 3.8+ (for agent samples)
  • Gemini API Key (for demo agents)
  • UV package manager (recommended for Python)

Quick Installation

Section titled “Quick Installation”

Clone the repository:

Set up your API key:

Running the Restaurant Finder Demo

Section titled “Running the Restaurant Finder Demo”

This demo showcases A2UI’s full capabilities with a Gemini-powered agent:

1. Start the backend agent:

2. Start the web client (Lit renderer):

3. Open your browser to http://localhost:5173 and start chatting!

Project Structure

Section titled “Project Structure”

Supported Renderers

Section titled “Supported Renderers”
FrameworkStatusNotes
LitAvailableDemonstrated in samples
AngularAvailableWeb components integration
FlutterAvailableGenUI SDK uses A2UI internally
ReactRoadmapPriority for v1.0
SwiftUIRoadmapiOS/macOS native
Jetpack ComposeRoadmapAndroid native

3. Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “3. Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Best Use Cases

Section titled “Best Use Cases”

1. Dynamic Form Generation

Section titled “1. Dynamic Form Generation”

Perfect for context-specific forms that adapt to user needs:

2. Multi-Agent Collaboration

Section titled “2. Multi-Agent Collaboration”

Remote agents can generate UIs within orchestrator contexts:

  • Agent A handles data retrieval
  • Agent B generates visualization cards
  • Orchestrator combines UIs seamlessly

3. Enterprise Automation

Section titled “3. Enterprise Automation”
  • Custom workflow dashboards
  • Approval interfaces
  • Real-time status visualizations

4. Cross-Platform Consistency

Section titled “4. Cross-Platform Consistency”

Same agent response renders natively on:

  • Web browsers
  • Mobile apps (iOS/Android)
  • Desktop applications

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Define Your Component Catalog

Start with a curated set of trusted components:

2. Keep Components Simple

Each component should have a single responsibility. Compose complex UIs from simple building blocks.

3. Use Data Binding Effectively

Separate UI structure from data model:

4. Handle Incremental Updates

Leverage A2UI’s flat structure for efficient partial updates:

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Work Scenario - Project Status Dashboard:

Life Scenario - Restaurant Discovery:

4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Precautions

Section titled “Important Precautions”
AreaRecommendation
SecurityOnly include components in your catalog that you trust. A2UI is declarative, not executable, but your renderer implementations must be secure
VersioningA2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). Expect breaking changes before v1.0
PerformanceFor complex UIs, consider pagination and lazy loading in your renderer
AccessibilityYour renderer is responsible for accessibility. A2UI provides structure; you provide semantics

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is A2UI different from sending HTML?

A: A2UI sends structured JSON that describes UI components. Your app renders these using native widgets, maintaining your design system, accessibility, and security. HTML/JS requires sandboxing and can’t integrate with native styling.

Q: Can agents execute arbitrary code through A2UI?

A: No. A2UI is a declarative data format. Agents can only request components from your pre-approved catalog. Your renderer decides how to present them.

Q: Does A2UI replace MCP (Model Context Protocol)?

A: No, they’re complementary. MCP connects agents to tools and data. A2UI defines how agents describe UIs. You can use both in the same system.

Q: What about AG-UI?

A: AG-UI is the transport layer for real-time agent-UI communication. A2UI defines the payload format. They work together beautifully.

Q: Is A2UI production-ready?

A: A2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). It’s functional but evolving. Production use should plan for specification updates.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Problem: Agent responses not rendering

Solution: Ensure your agent’s output matches the A2UI schema with proper delimiters.

Problem: Components not appearing

Solution: Verify the component type is in your catalog:

Problem: Data binding not updating

Solution: Check that your data model is properly initialized and the bind paths are correct:

5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis

Section titled “5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis”

The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape

Section titled “The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape”

In 2025, three complementary protocols have emerged as the foundation for agent-driven interfaces:

ProtocolPurposeCreatorFocus
A2UIDeclarative UI descriptionsGoogleWhat UI to render (payload)
MCPAgent-to-tool connectionsAnthropicHow agents access tools (vertical)
AG-UIReal-time agent-UI communicationCopilotKitHow UIs receive updates (transport)
A2AAgent-to-agent communicationGoogleHow agents talk to each other (horizontal)

A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison

Section titled “A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison”
AspectA2UIMCP-UI/MCP Apps
PhilosophyNative-first: “Blueprint” for native componentsWeb-first: HTML/JS in sandboxed iframes
RenderingApp renders using native widgetsBrowser renders sandboxed web content
StylingInherits host app stylingIsolated styling in sandbox
Security ModelComponent catalog restrictionIframe sandboxing
Cross-PlatformSame payload works on web, mobile, desktopPrimarily web-focused
Backed ByGoogleAnthropic, OpenAI

How They Work Together

Section titled “How They Work Together”

Comparative Analysis with Opal

Section titled “Comparative Analysis with Opal”

Opal (also from Google) uses A2UI as its underlying protocol:

  • Opal provides higher-level abstractions for AI mini-apps
  • A2UI provides the wire protocol for UI descriptions
  • Together they enable “one-sentence AI apps”

When to Use What

Section titled “When to Use What”
ScenarioRecommended Protocol
Native mobile app with AI featuresA2UI + AG-UI
Web chat with rich responsesMCP Apps or A2UI
Multi-agent orchestration with UIA2UI + A2A + AG-UI
Tool-calling with data accessMCP
Cross-platform consistencyA2UI

6. Reference Links

Section titled “6. Reference Links”

Official Resources

Section titled “Official Resources”
ResourceURL
A2UI Official Sitea2ui.org
GitHub Repositorygithub.com/google/A2UI
Google Developers Blog AnnouncementIntroducing A2UI
A2UI Composer (Widget Builder)go.copilotkit.ai/A2UI-widget-builder

Documentation

Section titled “Documentation”
TopicLink
What is A2UIa2ui.org/introduction/what-is-a2ui
Core Conceptsa2ui.org/core-concepts
Specificationa2ui.org/specification

Related Protocols

Section titled “Related Protocols”
ProtocolDocumentation
MCP (Model Context Protocol)modelcontextprotocol.io
A2A (Agent-to-Agent)a2aprotocol.ai
AG-UIcopilotkit.ai/ag-ui

Community & Learning

Section titled “Community & Learning”
ResourceDescription
CopilotKit BlogThe State of Agentic UI
DEV.to TutorialA2UI in Practice
Hacker News DiscussionA2UI Protocol Discussion

Roadmap

Section titled “Roadmap”

The A2UI team has prioritized:

  1. Specification stabilization (v1.0)
  2. React renderer (official support)
  3. Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI (native mobile)
  4. REST transport (production-ready)
  5. Integration with Genkit and LangGraph

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

A2UI represents a fundamental shift in how AI agents interact with users. Instead of text-only responses or risky code execution, agents can now describe rich, interactive UIs that render natively across platforms.

Key Takeaways:

  1. A2UI is declarative - It describes UIs, not executes code
  2. Security by design - Component catalog restricts what agents can request
  3. Framework-agnostic - One agent response works across web, mobile, desktop
  4. Composable - Works alongside MCP, AG-UI, and A2A for complete agent systems

As the agentic era accelerates, protocols like A2UI will become essential infrastructure for building AI applications that feel native, secure, and responsive.

Ready to build with A2UI? Start with the official quickstart or explore the GitHub samples.

item.title: Hugging Face Skills: Fine-Tune Any Open-Source LLM with Natural Language
item.content:encoded:
Turn Conversations Into Fine-Tuned Models — No ML Expertise Required

What Are Hugging Face Skills?

Section titled “What Are Hugging Face Skills?”

Hugging Face Skills is a revolutionary system that enables AI coding agents like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, and Google Gemini CLI to fine-tune open-source language models end-to-end through natural language conversations.

Instead of writing complex training scripts, configuring GPU resources, and managing deployment pipelines manually, you simply describe what you want in plain English:

The AI agent handles everything else: data validation, hardware selection, script generation, job submission, progress monitoring, and model publishing.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

End-to-End Automation

Section titled “End-to-End Automation”
CapabilityDescription
Data ValidationAutomatically checks dataset format compatibility before training
Hardware SelectionIntelligently picks the right GPU based on model size and budget
Script GenerationCreates production-ready training scripts with TRL library
Job SubmissionSubmits training jobs to Hugging Face cloud GPUs
Real-time MonitoringTracks progress via Trackio dashboard
Model PublishingPushes finished models to Hugging Face Hub
GGUF ConversionConverts models for local deployment with llama.cpp/Ollama

Supported Training Methods

Section titled “Supported Training Methods”
MethodBest ForExample Dataset
SFT (Supervised Fine-Tuning)Quality behavior examplesCustomer support conversations
DPO (Direct Preference Optimization)Preference-annotated dataChosen/rejected response pairs
GRPO (Group Relative Policy Optimization)Verifiable success criteriaMath problems, coding tasks

Multi-Platform Compatibility

Section titled “Multi-Platform Compatibility”
  • Anthropic Claude Code — Full integration via MCP protocol
  • OpenAI Codex — Uses AGENTS.md for instruction loading
  • Google Gemini CLI — Extensions-based integration
  • Coming Soon: Cursor, Windsurf, Continue

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Requirements

Section titled “Requirements”
  • Hugging Face Account with Pro or Team/Enterprise plan (Jobs require paid plan)

Alternative: MCP-based Installation

Authentication

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Scenario 1: Customer Support Bot Fine-Tuning

Section titled “Scenario 1: Customer Support Bot Fine-Tuning”

Expected Workflow:

  1. Agent validates dataset format (looks for “messages” column)
  2. Selects t4-medium hardware (~$0.75/hour)
  3. Configures training with appropriate batch size
  4. Submits job and provides monitoring link
  5. Pushes model to your-username/qwen-support-sft

Scenario 2: Code Assistant with Preference Learning

Section titled “Scenario 2: Code Assistant with Preference Learning”

Multi-stage Pipeline:

  • First stage creates base capabilities
  • Second stage aligns with human preferences
  • Agent handles both stages automatically

Scenario 3: Math Reasoning with GRPO

Section titled “Scenario 3: Math Reasoning with GRPO”

Best for:

  • Problems with correct/incorrect answers
  • Code generation with unit tests
  • Mathematical proofs

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

  1. Always Validate First

    This costs pennies and prevents $30+ failures.

  2. Start with Demo Runs

  3. Be Explicit for Production

  4. Monitor in Real-Time

    Get live loss curves, learning rate, and ETA.

Hardware and Cost Guide

Section titled “Hardware and Cost Guide”
Model SizeRecommended GPUTraining TimeEst. CostNotes
<1Bt4-small<1 hour$1-2Demo/testing
1-3Bt4-medium / a10g-small2-3 hours$5-15Small production
3-7Ba10g-large (LoRA)4-8 hours$15-40Medium production
7B+Not supported——Too large for this tool

Note: Models above 3B automatically use LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) to fit in memory while maintaining quality.

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: What’s the minimum cost to try this?

A: A demo run on 100 examples with t4-small costs approximately $0.30-0.50.

Q: Can I train models larger than 7B?

A: The current HF Skills system supports up to 7B. For larger models, use full Hugging Face infrastructure.

Q: Which dataset formats are supported?

A:

  • SFT: messages column with conversation format
  • DPO: chosen, rejected, and optionally prompt columns
  • GRPO: Dataset with verifiable correct answers

Q: How do I fix column name mismatches?

A: Ask the agent:

Common Issues and Solutions

Section titled “Common Issues and Solutions”
IssueSolution

Dataset Format ErrorRun validation first; agent identifies mismatches
Training TimeoutAdjust epoch count or use checkpointing
Authentication FailedVerify HF_TOKEN has write permissions

Pro Tips

Section titled “Pro Tips”
  1. Use Trackio Dashboard — Real-time training visualization at huggingface.co/spaces/username/trackio
  2. Convert to GGUF — Deploy locally without internet dependency
  3. Checkpoint Regularly — Recover from interruptions without losing progress

Comparison with Similar Products and Services

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Products and Services”

Hugging Face Skills vs. Traditional Fine-Tuning

Section titled “Hugging Face Skills vs. Traditional Fine-Tuning”
AspectTraditionalHF Skills
Setup TimeHours to daysMinutes

Coding Agent Comparison

Section titled “Coding Agent Comparison”

OpenAI CodexAGENTS.mdStrong code generation
Gemini CLIExtensionsGoogle ecosystem integration

Alternative Tools

Section titled “Alternative Tools”

Hugging Face AutoTrainGUI-based trainingVisual interface, less conversational
AWS SageMakerEnterprise MLMore complex, broader scope
Google Vertex AICloud MLTightly coupled with GCP
Together AIInference + TrainingFocus on API-first approach

Why Choose HF Skills?

  • Natural language interface
  • No code required
  • Cost-effective for small-to-medium models
  • Seamless Hub integration

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”

Official Resources

Section titled “Official Resources”

Training Method References

  • GGUF Conversion Guide

Community Resources

Section titled “Community Resources”
  • Hugging Face MCP Course
  • Agents-MCP-Hackathon
  • Smithery MCP Server Registry

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Hugging Face Skills represents a paradigm shift in how we approach model fine-tuning. By bridging the gap between natural language and machine learning infrastructure, it democratizes access to custom AI model creation.

Whether you’re a developer looking to create a specialized code assistant, a business building a customer support bot, or a researcher exploring new training methods, HF Skills provides an accessible, cost-effective, and powerful solution.

Get Started Today:

The future of AI model training is conversational. Welcome to the age of Skills.

item.title: n8n-skills: Build Flawless n8n Workflows with Claude Code
item.content:encoded:
Transform Your n8n Workflow Development with AI-Powered Skills

What is n8n-skills?

Section titled “What is n8n-skills?”

n8n-skills is a collection of 7 complementary Claude Code skills designed to teach AI assistants how to build production-ready n8n workflows using the n8n-mcp MCP server.

Created by Romuald Członkowski from AI Advisors, these skills solve the common challenges developers face when building n8n workflows programmatically.

Why n8n-skills Exists

Section titled “Why n8n-skills Exists”

Building n8n workflows programmatically can be challenging. Common issues include:

ChallengeHow n8n-skills Helps
Using MCP tools incorrectlyExpert guidance on tool selection
Validation error loopsValidation error interpretation and fixing
Unknown workflow patterns5 proven architectural patterns
Node misconfigurationOperation-aware node configuration
Expression syntax errorsCorrect {{}} patterns and variables

The 7 Skills

Section titled “The 7 Skills”

1. n8n Expression Syntax

Section titled “1. n8n Expression Syntax”

Teaches correct n8n expression syntax and common patterns.

Activates when: Writing expressions, using {{}} syntax, accessing $json/$node variables.

Key Features:

  • Core variables ($json, $node, $now, $env)
  • Critical gotcha: Webhook data is under $json.body
  • Common mistakes catalog with fixes
  • When NOT to use expressions (Code nodes!)

2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)

Section titled “2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)”

Expert guide for using n8n-mcp MCP tools effectively.

Key Features:

  • Tool selection guide (which tool for which task)
  • nodeType format differences (nodes-base.* vs n8n-nodes-base.*)
  • Validation profiles (minimal/runtime/ai-friendly/strict)
  • Smart parameters (branch=“true” for IF nodes)
  • Auto-sanitization system explained

3. n8n Workflow Patterns

Section titled “3. n8n Workflow Patterns”

Build workflows using 5 proven architectural patterns.

Key Features:

  • 5 proven patterns (webhook processing, HTTP API, database, AI, scheduled)
  • Workflow creation checklist
  • Real examples from 2,653+ n8n templates
  • Pattern selection guide

4. n8n Validation Expert

Section titled “4. n8n Validation Expert”

Interpret validation errors and guide fixing.

Key Features:

  • Validation loop workflow
  • Real error catalog
  • Auto-sanitization behavior explained
  • False positives guide

5. n8n Node Configuration

Section titled “5. n8n Node Configuration”

Operation-aware node configuration guidance.

Key Features:

  • Property dependency rules (e.g., sendBody → contentType)
  • Operation-specific requirements
  • AI connection types (8 types for AI Agent workflows)

6. n8n Code JavaScript

Section titled “6. n8n Code JavaScript”

Write effective JavaScript code in n8n Code nodes.

Key Features:

  • Data access patterns ($input.all(), $input.first(), $input.item)
  • Correct return format: [{json: {...}}]
  • Built-in functions ($helpers.httpRequest(), DateTime, $jmespath())
  • Top 5 error patterns with solutions (covering 62%+ of failures)
  • 10 production-tested patterns

7. n8n Code Python

Section titled “7. n8n Code Python”

Write Python code in n8n Code nodes with proper limitations awareness.

Key Features:

  • Important: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases
  • Critical limitation: No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Standard library reference (json, datetime, re, etc.)
  • Workarounds for missing libraries

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  1. n8n-mcp MCP server installed and configured (Installation Guide)
  2. Claude Code, Claude.ai, or Claude API access
  3. .mcp.json configured with n8n-mcp server

Method 1: Plugin Installation (Recommended)

Section titled “Method 1: Plugin Installation (Recommended)”

Method 2: Via Marketplace

Section titled “Method 2: Via Marketplace”

Method 3: Manual Installation

Section titled “Method 3: Manual Installation”

Recommended Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios”

1. Building Webhook-to-Slack Workflows

Section titled “1. Building Webhook-to-Slack Workflows”

2. Creating AI Agent Workflows

Section titled “2. Creating AI Agent Workflows”

Perfect for building intelligent automation with LangChain nodes:

  • AI connection types guidance
  • Memory and output parser configuration
  • Streaming mode constraints

3. Scheduled Data Processing

Section titled “3. Scheduled Data Processing”

Build reliable scheduled workflows:

  • Scheduled trigger configuration
  • Database integration patterns
  • Error handling best practices

4. API Integration Workflows

Section titled “4. API Integration Workflows”

Connect external services efficiently:

  • HTTP Request node configuration
  • Authentication patterns
  • Response handling

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Start with Templates

Section titled “1. Start with Templates”

Always check n8n’s 2,709 workflow templates before building from scratch:

2. Validate Early and Often

Section titled “2. Validate Early and Often”

Use the multi-level validation approach:

LevelProfileUse Case
1minimalQuick required fields check (<100ms)
2runtimeFull validation with fixes
3ai-friendlyBalanced for AI workflows
4strictComplete validation

3. Understand Property Dependencies

Section titled “3. Understand Property Dependencies”

Many n8n nodes have conditional properties:

4. Use Correct Expression Syntax

Section titled “4. Use Correct Expression Syntax”

FAQs & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQs & Troubleshooting”

Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?

Section titled “Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?”

A: Remember that webhook data is under $json.body, not directly in $json. This is the most common gotcha.

Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?

Section titled “Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?”

A: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases. Python has critical limitations:

  • No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Only standard library available

Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives

Section titled “Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives”

A: Use appropriate validation profiles:

  • minimal for quick checks during development
  • runtime for production-ready validation
  • Check the auto-sanitization behavior

Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?

Section titled “Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?”

A: Follow this order:

  1. search_templates - Check if templates exist
  2. search_nodes - Find required nodes
  3. get_node - Get configuration details
  4. validate_node - Validate your config
  5. validate_workflow - Final check

AspectWith n8n-skillsWithout
Learning curveGuided by AISelf-discovery

Featuren8nZapierMake
Self-hosted✅❌❌
Code nodes✅ Full JS/PythonLimitedLimited
AI integration✅ LangChainBasicBasic
Open source✅❌❌
MCP support✅ via n8n-mcp❌❌

Related Tools in the Ecosystem

Section titled “Related Tools in the Ecosystem”
ToolPurpose
n8n-mcpMCP server for n8n (required)
n8nWorkflow automation platform
Claude CodeAI coding assistant

What’s Included

  • 7 complementary skills that work together
  • 525+ n8n nodes supported
  • 2,653+ workflow templates for examples
  • 10 production-tested Code node patterns
  • Comprehensive error catalogs and troubleshooting guides

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

n8n-skills transforms the way you build n8n workflows with Claude Code:

  1. Automatic activation - Skills trigger when relevant queries are detected
  2. Composable design - All 7 skills work together seamlessly
  3. Production-ready patterns - Based on real-world usage
  4. Validation first - Catch errors before deployment

Whether you’re building simple webhook integrations or complex AI agent workflows, n8n-skills provides the guidance you need to build flawless automation.

  • n8n-skills GitHub

item.title: Gemini CLI Conductor: Context-Driven Development That Plans Before It Codes
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Benjamin Franklin once said: “Failing to plan is planning to fail.”

This wisdom applies perfectly to AI-assisted coding. While tools like ChatGPT and Claude excel at answering questions, they often fall short when it comes to complex, multi-session projects where context gets lost between conversations.

Enter Conductor - a game-changing extension for Gemini CLI that introduces Context-Driven Development. Instead of treating AI interactions as fleeting chat logs, Conductor helps you create formal specifications and plans that live alongside your code as persistent Markdown files.

What is Conductor?

Section titled “What is Conductor?”

Conductor is a preview extension for Gemini CLI that transforms how you work with AI on code projects. Its core philosophy is simple but powerful:

“Treat context as a managed artifact alongside your code.”

Rather than depending on impermanent chat logs, Conductor helps you:

  • Create formal specifications before writing code
  • Maintain persistent context across sessions
  • Build implementation plans that guide the AI’s behavior
  • Keep your repository as the single source of truth

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Plan Before Implementation

Section titled “1. Plan Before Implementation”

Conductor enforces a structured workflow: Context → Spec & Plan → Implement. This ensures you think through requirements before diving into code.

2. Persistent Context Files

Section titled “2. Persistent Context Files”

All project context is stored in Markdown files that:

  • Survive beyond individual chat sessions
  • Can be version-controlled with Git
  • Enable team collaboration with shared standards

3. Hierarchical Task Organization

Section titled “3. Hierarchical Task Organization”

Work is organized into a clear hierarchy:

  • Tracks - High-level work units (features, bug fixes)
  • Phases - Major stages within a track
  • Tasks - Individual implementation steps

4. Brownfield-Friendly

Section titled “4. Brownfield-Friendly”

Unlike many AI tools that struggle with existing codebases, Conductor excels at “brownfield” development - working with mature projects where architectural nuance matters.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with Conductor is straightforward:

The --auto-update flag ensures you always have the latest version.

Prerequisites:

  • Gemini CLI installed and configured
  • Git repository initialized
  • Node.js (for Gemini CLI)

Commands Reference

Section titled “Commands Reference”

Conductor provides five core commands:

CommandPurpose
/conductor:setupInitial project configuration (run once per project)
/conductor:newTrackBegin a new feature or bug fix
/conductor:implementExecute planned tasks
/conductor:statusView current progress
/conductor:revertUndo work logically (tracks/phases/tasks, not commits)

Pro Tip: Add a description to newTrack: /conductor:newTrack "Add user authentication"

The Context-Driven Workflow

Section titled “The Context-Driven Workflow”

Step 1: Setup Your Project

Section titled “Step 1: Setup Your Project”

Run /conductor:setup to establish your project’s foundational context:

This creates configuration files for:

  • Product Definition - Users, goals, features
  • Tech Stack - Languages, frameworks, databases
  • Workflow Preferences - TDD approach, commit strategies
  • Code Style Guides - Formatting, naming conventions

Step 2: Create a New Track

Section titled “Step 2: Create a New Track”

When starting new work, create a track:

This generates:

  • spec.md - Detailed requirements document
  • plan.md - Actionable task breakdown with phases

Step 3: Review Before Implementation

Section titled “Step 3: Review Before Implementation”

Critical: Conductor requires human review of plans before implementation begins. This is your chance to refine requirements and catch issues early.

Step 4: Implement

Section titled “Step 4: Implement”

Execute the plan:

Conductor will work through tasks systematically, maintaining state so you can pause and resume across sessions.

Generated File Structure

Section titled “Generated File Structure”

After setup, your project will include:

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Run Setup Once Per Project

Section titled “1. Run Setup Once Per Project”

The setup command establishes shared team standards. Run it once, then commit the generated files.

2. Review Plans Carefully

Section titled “2. Review Plans Carefully”

Plans require human approval before implementation. Take time to refine them - it’s much cheaper to fix a plan than to refactor code.

3. Monitor Token Usage

Section titled “3. Monitor Token Usage”

Context-heavy operations consume more tokens. Use /stats model to track consumption.

4. Use Logical Revert

Section titled “4. Use Logical Revert”

The /conductor:revert command reverts based on tracks/phases/tasks rather than Git commits, providing safer rollbacks.

5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation

Section titled “5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation”

Your conductor files aren’t just for AI - they’re valuable documentation for your team.

Conductor vs. Other AI Tools

Section titled “Conductor vs. Other AI Tools”
FeatureStandard Chat AIConductor
Context PersistenceSession-onlyPermanent files
PlanningOptionalEnforced
Team CollaborationCopy-paste chaosShared configs
Brownfield SupportLimitedExcellent
State ManagementNoneBuilt-in checkpoints

vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform

Section titled “vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform”

While both are AI-powered, they serve different purposes:

  • Conductor = Project manager for day-to-day coding
  • Amazon Transform = Large-scale migrations (e.g., Java 8 → Java 17)

vs. Cursor/Claude Code

Section titled “vs. Cursor/Claude Code”

Conductor complements rather than replaces IDE-integrated AI:

  • Use Conductor for planning and specification
  • Use Cursor/Claude for in-editor implementation

Real-World Scenarios

Section titled “Real-World Scenarios”

Scenario 1: New Feature Development

Section titled “Scenario 1: New Feature Development”

Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation

Section titled “Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation”

Scenario 3: Team Onboarding

Section titled “Scenario 3: Team Onboarding”

New developer joins? They can:

  1. Read conductor/product.md for product context
  2. Review conductor/tech-stack.md for technical decisions
  3. Check conductor/workflow.md for conventions
  4. Start contributing immediately with consistent guidelines

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
Extension not foundEnsure Gemini CLI is updated to latest version
Setup failsCheck you have write permissions in the repository
Context too largeUse /stats model to monitor; consider splitting work
Plan generation slowLarge codebases may require patience during analysis

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?

Section titled “Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?”

A: Yes! Conductor is specifically designed for “brownfield” development. The setup command analyzes your existing codebase to understand patterns.

Q: Can I edit generated plans?

Section titled “Q: Can I edit generated plans?”

A: Absolutely. Plans are Markdown files - edit them as needed before implementation.

Q: Is my code sent to Google?

Section titled “Q: Is my code sent to Google?”

A: Conductor uses Gemini API. Review Google’s AI terms and your organization’s policies.

Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?”

A: Yes. The generated specs and plans are valuable input for any AI assistant.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Conductor represents a paradigm shift in AI-assisted development. By treating context as a first-class artifact and planning as a mandatory step, it addresses the core weakness of chat-based AI coding: loss of context and lack of structure.

Key takeaways:

  • Plan first, code second - Conductor enforces specification before implementation
  • Context is king - Persistent files ensure nothing gets lost between sessions
  • Team-ready - Shared configurations enable consistent AI interactions across developers
  • Brownfield-capable - Works with your existing codebase, not against it

The future of AI coding isn’t just about generating code faster - it’s about generating the right code, consistently. Conductor is a significant step in that direction.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Conductor: Introducing context-driven development for Gemini CLI - Google Developers Blog
  • Conductor GitHub Repository
  • Gemini CLI Official Repository
  • Spec-Driven Development with Gemini CLI - Medium

item.title: BMAD Installation & Configuration Guide: Best Practices for Project-Level Setup

BMAD (Build More, Architect Dreams) is an AI-driven agile development methodology framework that integrates multiple AI Agents, workflows, and modules. It supports 18+ IDEs including Claude Code, Codex, and Cursor. This guide walks you through the complete installation and configuration process for BMAD v6.0.0-alpha.

1 | Why Project-Level Installation?

Section titled “1 | Why Project-Level Installation?”

Key Recommendation: Install BMAD in your project directory, NOT in your user home directory.

Benefits:

  • Isolation: Each project has independent BMAD configuration
  • Version Control: Project-level config can be tracked with Git
  • Team Collaboration: Team members get identical configs when cloning
  • Multi-Project Support: Different projects can use different BMAD versions

Post-installation directory structure:

The .bmad configuration directory contains these submodules:

2 | Prerequisites

Section titled “2 | Prerequisites”

Ensure you have:

  • Node.js (v18+ recommended)
  • Bun or npm/npx
  • Claude Code or another supported IDE

3 | Starting Installation

Section titled “3 | Starting Installation”

Run in your project root directory:

You’ll see the BMAD ASCII logo:

4 | Configuration Options Explained

Section titled “4 | Configuration Options Explained”

4.1 Installation Directory

Section titled “4.1 Installation Directory”

Recommendation: Use your current project directory and confirm with Yes.

4.2 BMad Optimized Builder (BoMB) Module

Section titled “4.2 BMad Optimized Builder (BoMB) Module”
